In logic, a conditional statement "If P, then Q" does not imply that if P is false, Q must also be false. The only situation where a conditional statement is false is when P is true and Q is false. If P is false, the conditional statement "If P, then Q" is considered true regardless of the truth value of Q.

The second statement given is "The apple was not red," which means P is false. According to the rules of logic, when P is false, the conditional statement "If P, then Q" does not provide any information about the truth value of Q. Therefore, we cannot infer anything about the truth value of Q, which is "The banana was yellow."
